generif.text: Both the high affinity thrombin receptor (GPIb-IX-V) and GPIIb/IIIa are implicated in expression of thrombin-induced platelet procoagulant activity.
Lateral clustering of platelet GP Ib-IX complexes leads to up-regulation of the adhesive function of integrin alpha IIbbeta 3
The cysteine knot of platelet GPIb beta is critical for the interaction of GPIb beta with GPIX.
PKA-mediated phosphorylation of GPIbbeta at Ser(166) negatively regulates VWF binding to GPIb-IX and is one of the mechanisms by which PKA mediates platelet inhibition
Novel nonsense mutation is associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
structure-activity relationship of mutations found in Bernard-Soulier syndrome
factor XI is localized to GPIb in membrane rafts and this association is important for promoting the activation of factor XI by thrombin on the platelet surface

findings indicate that the Ala14-->Thr mutation in the transmembrane region of GP IX does not induce intracellular GP Ib/IX complex degradation, but prevents its insertion in the cytoplasmic membrane of platelets and CHO cells
Observational study of genetic testing. (HuGE Navigator)

3 families from Iran with Bernard-Soulier syndrome were investigated; the presence of the same GpIX Phe55Ser missense mutation in two families and of a single base insertion (GP1BA C3221 ins) in the third family were demonstrated
the first non-Caucasian Turkish Bernard-Soulier syndrome case due to GPIX N45S and is likely the result of a recurrent mutational event.
The transmembrane domain of GPIX plays an important role in expression and assembly of the GPIb-IX complex by interacting with its counterparts of GPIb.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)

Polymorphisms in human platelet alloantigen (HPA)-1 and HPA-3 (GPIIb/IIIa), HPA-2 (GPIb/IX), HPA-4 (GPIIIa) and HPA-5 (GPIa/IIa) were found to be associated with the symptoms and recurrence of ischemic stroke.
laminin supports platelet adhesion depending on the interaction of VWF and GPIb-IX-V under pathophysiological high shear flow
glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex contributes to tissue factor-independent thrombin generation by recombinant factor VIIa on the activated platelet surface
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)

Data demonstrate the native-like heteromeric interaction among the isolated Ibalpha, Ib beta and IX TM peptides, which provides support for the four-helix bundle model of the TM domains in the glycoprotein Ib-IX complex.

Findings point to a role of the GPIb-V-IX complex intrinsic to megakaryocytes at the stage of proplatelet formation and suggest a functional link with the underlying microtubular cytoskeleton in platelet biogenesis.
Homozygous missense mutation in position 1829 (A(R)G) of the GPIX gene causes Bernard-Soulier syndrome in a Swiss family.
14-3-3beta, 14-3-3gamma, 14-3-3epsilon, 14-3-3eta and 14-3-3theta isoforms interact with the GPIb-IX complex in platelets
the putative convex surface of the LRR domain in GPIX is sufficient, in the context of full-length subunit, to mediate its association with GPIbbeta

Raft association and cytoskeletal linkage of the platelet GPIb-IX-V complex are interrelated and are required for optimal receptor function, by attracting signaling proteins and membrane skeletal association allows proteins to move to new locations.
GP Ibbeta/GP IX mediates the disulfide-linked GP Ibalpha localization to the GEMs, which is critical for vWf interaction at high shear

GPIIb/IIIa is the primary receptor set involved in platelet adhesion to adsorbed fibrinogen and serum albumin irrespective of their degree of adsorption-induced unfolding, while the GPIb-IX-V receptor complex plays an insignificant role.
Report glycoprotein Ib/IX complex mutations found in Bernard-Soulier syndrome in Indian patients.

GPIbbeta missense mutations from Bernard-Soulier syndrome were examined for changes to GPIb-IX complex surface expression. Mutations A108P and P74R were found to maintain normal secretion/folding of GPIbbeta(E) but were unable to support GPIX surface expression
GPIX increased the expression of GPIba by promoting the formation of a disulfide bond between GPIba and GPIbb in transfected CHO-K1 cells.

Studies indicate that platelets from Bernard-Soulier syndrome (BSS) are defective in glycoprotein (GP)Ib-IX-V, a platelet-specific adhesion-signaling complex, composed of GPIbalpha disulfide linked to GPIbbeta, and noncovalently associated with GPIX and GPV.

genetic association study in population in western India: Data suggest novel mutations in platelet glycoprotein Ib (GP1BA, GP1BB) and GP9 are associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome in subjects studies; of 12 mutations identified, ten were novel.
Data show that localization of the GP Ib-IX complex to the lipid domain is mediated by GP Ibbeta and GP IX transmembrane domains.
Case Report: suggest that alloantibodies directed against Cab4b, the first human platelet antigen carried by glycoprotein IX, can induce severe neonatal thrombocytopenia.
ERK5 associates with CKII to play essential roles in GPIb-IX-mediated platelet activation via the PTEN/PI3K/Akt pathway.
Oxidation shuts down an auto-inhibitory mechanism of von Willebrand factor.

BP.term: release of sequestered calcium ion into cytosol
release of sequestered calcium ion into cytosol

name: glycoprotein IX platelet

reactome.name: Intrinsic Pathway of Fibrin Clot Formation
Defects of contact activation system (CAS) and kallikrein/kinin system (KKS)
Defective factor IX causes hemophilia B
Defects of platelet adhesion to exposed collagen
Enhanced binding of GP1BA variant to VWF multimer:collagen
Defective binding of VWF variant to GPIb:IX:V

summary: This gene encodes a small membrane glycoprotein found on the surface of human platelets. It forms a 1-to-1 noncovalent complex with glycoprotein Ib, a platelet surface membrane glycoprotein complex that functions as a receptor for von Willebrand factor. The complete receptor complex includes noncovalent association of the alpha and beta subunits with the protein encoded by this gene and platelet glycoprotein V. Defects in this gene are a cause of Bernard-Soulier syndrome, also known as giant platelet disease. These patients have unusually large platelets and have a clinical bleeding tendency. [provided by RefSeq, Oct 2008].
